text: The kids compared this top building your own operation game, which is pretty much accurate. My 8, 10, and 11 year olds were able to complete this without any adult help- just following along with the instruction manual. Really, though, the pieces are so cheap and the outcome of the projects is essentially useless. The game boards are thin cardboard- barely thicker than cardstock. The connections are done with copper tape. I'm just really not impressed with the quality of the set. There are other circuit style learning tools to learn about how a circuit works.

title: Baby Likes It
text: My five month old loves this ball. The shape is a bit more flat than round. I'm not sure if it is supposed to be that way or if it just gets smooshed in packaging. I squeezed it back into a ball shape and it flattens back out. Either way, my baby love it. It has a soft chime inside that makes noise when you shake or roll it. The fabric is a soft velour that feels really nice to rub. It isn't so stuffed that the baby can't grab it. The ears also provide a way for baby to grab the ball and pick it up. The colors are soft and muted. It is a very well made toy. And the baby likes it.

title: Pixel Loom
text: The rainbow loom craze is pretty much over, but no one told my kids. They have top level rainbow loom skills. This loom just upped whatthey could accomplish on the rainbow loom. It lets them make wide bracelets with the little rainbow loom rubber bands. They can make words or pictures. Their favorite is making emojis. I'm just glad I can still find rainbow loom stuff because they love creating things on these. The 6 year old found this loom too difficult. He has to stick to the basic loom. But the 8, 10, and 11 year olds took to this thing very quickly.

title: Triceratops
text: My four year old is obsessed with dinosaurs. He loves them. He absolutely loves this triceratops. It is really big. He loves that he has a “cuddle dinosaur”. It is really well made. Very happy with this guy.

title: 100 Different Colors
text: My 11 year old loves these colored pencils. You get 100 colored pencils that are all different colors. 100 colors! They come presharpened. This is an excellent pack. The pencils are good quality colored pencils. The "lead" is a bit soft and on the slippery side for colored pencils. Great for detailed coloring books.

title: Oh The Tags
text: This iOS a cute toy. She is soft. She has a rattle in her head that isn't too very loud. Her body has crinkle paper inside. The arms and legs are a nice size for baby to grab and hold. The C clip on her head makes her easy to take on the go or swap out in the bouncer or playmat. Really, the only thing I hate about this toy isn't the toy company's fault. (Which is why I'm not deducting any stars for it.) These ridiculous tags on baby items just has to stop. Her tag is bigger than her arms and legs and is basically a book. It is beyond ridiculous. And they seem too big to try to cut off. They don't put the tag in the product picture, but it is definitely a prominent part of the toy.

title: Apples
text: My kids are really loving this game. The 8, 10, and 11 year old beg me to play this every night after dinner. It is a great game. I love the feel of the tiles. The Apple is cute and the best part is yelling, “How do you like them apples?!” When you win.

title: Fun!
text: I decided to introduce my kids to Boggle and boy do they love it! The timer is a little on the quick side for my 8 year old. But we all have a really fun time playing! The case on this one is a little difficult to open. I keep thinking it will ooosen with use, but so far, it hasn't.

title: Sweet Baby Doll
text: My boys think the doll is the best ever. She is the size of a newborn. She fits into newborn clothes and diapers. She has a slightly weighted bottom, so she feels substantial. Her eyes open and close as you lean her back. The arms and legs rotate. I could have done without the cheap accessories, but she does come with a doll diaper, birth certificate, swaddle bag, and paci.

title: Not The Best
text: These are cute in the box. But then you get them out. They aren't very well made. The lion with the bells makes me super nervous. I'm constantly worried about those bells falling out and becoming a choking hazard. The elephant doesn't shake very loudly. It is a very lack-luster shaker. The giraffe's horn is a stick to use on the giraffe's neck. Which is cute and fine- until you lose it. I have had much better instruments for kids.

title: Learn the Continents
text: This is great for younger kids. I used this puzzle globe while teaching my younger kids geography. We talked about the continents while putting this puzzle globe together. It was a lot of fun and the hands on aspect helped them remember not only the continents, but where they were located as well.

title: Thomas Tornado
text: This is a really cute set. It isn't like the wooden Thomas sets. This one is plastic. We used this track with my 2, 4, and 6 year old while we were talking about weather. It was a great toy to have fun, but tie into learning something important. “Oh no! Thomas doesn't know what to do in a tornado! We should teach him!” So it was a fun, non-scary way to incorporate some storm preparedness with the younger kids.

title: Annoying Stickers
text: My preschooler is learning his letters, so I thought these blocks would be a great way to get in some letter practice. The block come in a reusable bag, which I actually like. However, the block aren't stickered in any way. They come with stickers for you to add to the blocks yourself. That is extremely annoying to me. The stickers don't stick well and quickly look very ragged. The blocks themselves are fine. Just the sticker application is annoying. I would much prefer for them to come already stickered.

title: Good Set
text: My boys are really liking the City Police Wild River sets. They have the typical Lego City feel, with some little absurdities thrown in there. This set is one of the smaller ones. It took my 6 and 8 year old less than half an hour to complete this set. It goes really well with the bigger sets. And you get some fun new people!

title: Really Fun Game
text:
This game has a lot of rules. It is difficult to learn at first, but once you get it, it is really fun. There are 4 players maximum. The box says it is for ages 10 and up. But my 8 year old found it just as easy to follow along as the rest of us. My 4 and 6 year olds were able to play along with help from an older sibling at times to remind them of the rules. If they played it a few more times, I'm sure they'd have it.
You have 4 monsters that are competing to be the Kaiju of a city. You set up the game board, which is a bunch of heavy cardboard card squares, new each game. The game is always different. Less players, less cards. You draw your moves. Your monster only moves a specific way. Your monsters battle in an amped up rock-paper-scissor style battle to see who wins. You tally your points, and the best monster is the new Kaiju! It sounds weird, and it is a little complicated, but just keep the rule book handy and you'll get it in no time.

title: So Cute
text: This pig came smaller than I expected. I don't know why I thought it would be bigger than a standard sized pillow. It is so soft. You can get it a bit more flat if you want, but it does hold its shape pretty well. It feels like a micro-velour, if that is even a thing.

title: Board Books
text: These books are really cute. I like the little garage they come in. The pages of these board books are really, really thick. My only complaint is the binding on the books. It is just tape. It looks unfinished to me and isn't very durable for toddlers, who these books are intended to be for. However, they aren't great works of literature, so will it really matter if they are a little rough on these? My two year old loves them. But I don't think they'll last very long in his care.

title: Cute Poppy
text: My two year old loves Trolls. Poppy is his favorite. He absolutely loves this doll. I'd be happier if her dress didn't come off because I am constantly redressing Poppy. The actual hair doesn't have much to do. I'm wishing they had just skipped trying to add accessory items. Her hair is brushable. And that is about it. My two year old just likes carrying her around naked, so it works well for his purposes. It reminds me of a giant Polly Pocket. They have similar dress styles. Cute doll.

title: Great Set
text: My boys said, “Make sure you say in your review that this Lego Set is awesome!” Clearly, they love it. It took my 10 and 8 year old about 2.5 hours to build the entire set. Their favorite parts were the helicopters. My 6 year old loves the car. It was a great set for them to work on together. Lots of different parts that all work together.

title: Lego Tape
text: These are genius! My ten year old absolutely loves this stuff. You can cut the tape with scissors to be any length you like. You can stick it anywhere. My son has placed strips on the underside of a bunk on his bunk bed to keep his favorite creations and people safe from his little brothers. Such a great idea!

title: Learn to Play Chess
text: My ten year old wanted to learn to play chess. This set is perfect! When you start, you can play by drawing a card and moving how it tells you to move. It teaches you the rules as you go. As you get more confident, you can use the cards as a reminder. Eventually, you can play chess without the cards. Great set to learn to play the game!

title: Good Kuchi Kopi
text: It is Kuchi Kopi, you cant go wrong. You “charge” Kuchi Kopi with a standard light. Turn off the lights and Kuchi Kopi glows! I feel like this one is the best size and feel to be most like the TV show.

title: Mystery Packs
text: I don't even know what a Mashem is, but apparently my kids so. They loved these things. They love mystery packs of anything, and I'll admit, mystery packaging is quite addictive. Like gambling. But with toys. And you won't lose your house. These are the cute girl superhero set. I wish they'd just mix all the superhero's in and you didn't have to pick the boy or girl packs. Kind of takes away some of the surprise.

title: Riddler
text: This is a fun Lego set with the Riddler and Batman. You also get two other characters and a jet pack. The car is really awesome looking once put together. It too my six and ten year old about an hour to put this together. (It would have been quicker if the six year old wasn't helping.) A fun set for Batman fans.

title: Troll Hair
text: This was such a big hit. My toddler has two loves. Play-Doh and Trolls. He absolutely LOVES this set. My four, six, eight, and eleven year olds take turns playing with him and his “troll hair”. It comes with 7 small containers of Play-Doh. You can use the hair mold to mold troll hair or use the chair to let the trolls grow hair. Use the scissors to give the trolls a hair cut. This has provided hours of fun.

title: Dory
text: These are cute little bath squirters. If you want them to last longer, convert them to non-squirting toys by using hot glue to seal the holes. That will make them so they float and can be played with in the tub, but won't mold on the inside, as squirting toys tend to do. They came in a little mesh bag.

title: Great Bath Toy
text: I love these simple boats. My toddler loves baths. There boats are a perfect bath toy. He can use them as boats or flip them upside down and use them as cups. He loves them. I love that they stack nicely when not in use. They are super simple and super fun.

title: Guy Diamond
text: My toddler loves trolls. He loves Poppy and Guy Diamond. This little doll isn't as sparkly as Guy Diamond really is, but who wants to cuddle with a ball of glitter? He is a really nice size for a carry around type of stuffed animal.

title: Imaginext Fight
text: My boys LOVE Imaginext. They are the perfect size for toddlers on up through bigger kids. This set is a lot of fun. It reminds me of the Rock ‘Em Sock ‘Em robots. They don't really get close enough to fist fight efficiently, but there are a few weapons included that you can put in their hands and make them joust it out. Or you can turn on the music and they are dancing! This set is fun. You can put any Imaginext character in here and let them duke it out.

title: Excellent Quality
text: We bought this Jellycat Bunny with the Dance Bunny book by Jellycat. The Bunny is small, but is the perfect size for a baby. I'd think she'd be lovely for an older child, as well. She is super well made. And her fur is so, so soft. She feels amazing. I love the lone arms and legs that make it easy for baby to grab and hold. Her little tutu gives a different feel on her, which is interesting and fun for a baby. I'm really impressed with the quality of this toy. I will happily buy Jellycat stuffies in the future!

title: Good
text: I was really curious how these would compare to standard Crayola colored pencils. The difference is really only exterior. These are black with the color indicated on the bottom. The box, however, doesn't let you see the colored bit on the bottom of the pencil, so it is really difficult to tell the color while using the box. The colors are also pretty off from the color on the bottom. Thee re hexagon shaped, so they won't roll away from you. The actual pencil “lead” seems exactly the same as standard Crayola colored pencils. I compared them side by side and they color the same. They both have fairly soft “lead”. These are sharpened better in their presharpened state. The standard Crayola colored pencil also appear to have a bit of a chalky residue on the “lead” and these don't, but I didn't find that to change how they function in any way. These look a little more high end, but color pretty much the same as a Crayola colored pencil. These don't feel like fine art quality, just hobby/craft quality. They are good for adult coloring books, which is what I got them for, so I'm happy with them. They just aren't the quality of higher end colored pencils as they are packaged to have you believe.

title: Ballerina Bunny
text: This book is adorable. It is really well made. I was surprised to find that it is a touch and feel book. We bought it with the pink Jellycat ballerina bunny, who is the main character of this book.

title: Pretty Awful
text: This is really cheap quality in person. It looks and feels like a claw machine toy. I expected it to be on the small side, which was totally fine. I did not expect the very acrylic, cheap feeling of the fur. It is patchy looking. I'm not happy with this at all.

title: Vinyl Clings, Not Stickers
text: My 4 year old dinosaur fanatic LOVES this. It isn't stickers at all, though. They are vinyl clings. I had to remove them from the sheets because my 4 year old couldn't get them off the backing paper without splitting the paper. There are five glossy paper scenes. The paper is really thick cardstock. The vinyl clings can be applied and removed and reapplied. There are way more clings than places to put them, so they can make different scenes over and over. I've been storing the clings in a ziplock bag. I think a binder with glossy dividers or plastic sleeves would work better, but I haven't opted to tackle that project since he is happy with the baggie.

title: Fun Activity
text: This is a fun craft that is precut and ready to go. Sure, you could make this without the kit- but it would likely cost you about the same or more and you'd have the work of cutting all the pieces out. This kit is perfect for kids 10 and older to work completely independently. It says 8 and up, but my 8 year old doesn't have the direction following skills to do it completely alone. Under 10, expect to need to help guide the kid a bit more and show them how to do some things. It would be great for the 6-9 age group to work on motor skills. This is a cute gift for any kid or tween. It is a fun activity, and the focus should really be on the enjoyment of creating. The actual finished project isn't really anything to write home about. They'll love it because they made it.

title: Fun Tracks
text:
My sons love this. It is a lot of fun to build tacks with bends and hills. I'm not sure why, but glow in the dark seems to make everything more fun for school aged boys. The toy itself is fun. It is creative. They like it.
My only real issue is how limited it is. You have to use the car that comes with. It doesn't “go” with any of the other thousand car tracks we already own. So, if I was going to choose between Hot Wheels Tracks or Magic Tracks, I'd go with the Hot Wheels tracks- just because of availability and more track options plus more car options. As a mom, it is just easier when toys that are like kind will work together. There are other track additions you can purchase for the Magic Tracks, but there isn't much variety. And you can purchase additional cars, but again, not much variety.

title: Great Bath Fun
text:
A fun bathtime doll! My 2 year old is a doll fanatic. This doll could be super messy if you're not using it in the bathtub. I like that the doll has a variety of hygiene products, so we can play and model brushing teeth when he isn't in the mood to brush his teeth. He can wash the doll and we can wash him. It just makes bathtime more fun for him and he is more cooperative with being bathed. Plus, it is really cute. And the doll comes with it's own little towel. You can pretend without water, but you need warm water to activate the “dirty to clean” spots.
I don't find the limited bath time use a bad thing. I'd rather bath toys stay in the bathroom. Just reserve this doll for bathtime only. Some dolls go in the bath. Some don't. Really, if I could change one thing about this product it would be to tone down the pink and choose another color. Not that there is anything wrong with pink, it'd just be nice to have other colors sometimes.

title: Cheap
text: This is a cute idea, but the actual set leaves much to be desired. The activities are all just cheaply made. You'd be better off buying some craft supplies and picking some activities off Pinterest. I would give it one star, because I have put together activities that are much more fun from the Dollar Store, but my 4 year old does love it. (My 2 year old and 6 year old were not at all impressed.) So, I'll give it a couple extra stars for his enjoyment.

title: Pony Play
text: This is such a cute set. You can model and make cute ponies and rainbows and things. The little molds are easy to use, even for preschoolers. The toddler can't quite figure out the molds, but likes trying. This is a fun modeling dough set.

title: Clayface
text: My 10 year old was able to build this set by himself in about an hour. He said the Clayface was a little more of a challenge because it isn't “normal” Lego blocks. The Clayface shoots from his hands, which the kids think is awesome. It also comes with a Batman and a Mayor.

title: So Fun
text: My kids and I have had the most fun playing this game! I don't know why they recommended it for older ages. My 6, 8, 10, and 11 year olds have been having a blast playing with me. You're given a situation (lifetime supply of beef jerky, the power to heal people, you fall in love...) and everyone comes up with the best way to ruin that for you. Like being a genie and trying to mess up wishes. (You have a lifetime supply of beef jerky, but no teeth. You have the power to heal people but you take their illness. You fall in love but she hates you.- You get the picture.) It is hillarious. It is fun to break out even if you only have a few minutes to spare. My kids beg me to play all the time now.

title: A Tool Box Like Grown Ups!
text: My little kids are always trying to get into the toolbox. So much fun stuff in there! Now, they have their own tool box with their own fun stuff! Yes, this has some parts that are small, but not too small for toddlers. (Too small for babies.) The set is really cute and will keep little ones pretending to work around the house for hours! My 2, 4, and 6 year olds all love this set!

title: Great for Toddlers
text: I love these bristle blocks for toddlers. They are so easy for them to put together and take apart. I love the colors. And the shapes add some added interest in their building projects.

title: Tween Crafts
text: Excellent craft kit for a tween. It has several different mermaid projects for them to complete and enjoy. Simple enough that an 11 year old can do this completely independently. Younger kids might need a little help. Although, the mermaid scales in a bottle is pretty creepy. How would one obtain mermaid scales, and for what purpose? You go skin a mermaid? That one seemed a bit weird. But it was sparkly, so, it was loved despite the creepy factor.

title: Not A Bath Toy
text: My toddler is baby doll crazy. He just LOVES them. I had hoped he could use this doll in the bath tub while he took a bath. I guess I took the “bathing” a little too literally. This is NOT a bath toy. This is a soft doll. If you submerge it in bathwater, it will take quite a while to dry out AND the smell will basically be gone. So, don't do that. Instead, give the baby doll a PRETEND bath without water. We have Bath Baby Stella watch our bath from the sink while she pretend bathes in the sink with her bath things. She is well made. And he loves her. I just really wish she was an actual bath toy.

title: Fun
text: If your kids are How to Train Your Dragon fans, these Playmobile sets might be for you. These are excellent for imaginative play. This set comes with the ship and father Captain. Good quality. Fun. These aren't great for the younger crowd, because they do have smallish parts included. This particular set is larger. However, if you're only getting one set, get one of the ones with the dragon and rider, because the kids seem to like those more. This one is a great addition to an existing How to Train Your Dragon set.

title: Memory Game
text: This is basically just a turn the card over memory game. However, you have the added fun factor of a shoe and asking “What did I step in?” This made it more fun for my 4 and 6 year old boys. But essentially, it is a memory game. You could use other memory game cards with this game and mix things up a bit.

title: Berk
text: If your kids are How to Train Your Dragon fans, these Playmobile sets might be for you. These are excellent for imaginative play. This set is pretty large. You'll have to get dragons separately. This is the finishing touch on Your How to Train Your Dragon Set. It is not suitable for younger kids because of all the small parts.

title: Dragon
text: If your kids are How to Train Your Dragon fans, these Playmobile sets might be for you. These are excellent for imaginative play. This set comes with the dragon and his rider. Good quality. Fun. These aren't great for the younger crowd, because they do have smallish parts included.

title: Dragon
text: If your kids are How to Train Your Dragon fans, these Playmobile sets might be for you. These are excellent for imaginative play. This set comes with the dragon and his rider. Good quality. Fun. These aren't great for the younger crowd, because they do have smallish parts included.

title: Great Toy
text: I was hesitant to try bristle blocks, but I'm glad I did. These are great for my toddler who gets frustrated trying to put Legos together. These go together and come apart more easily for him and with a lower frustration factor. I love the little box these come in. It makes cleaning them up and putting them away so much easier. This is definitely a great set and a great toy.

title: Llama
text: This craft set is a little much more “done” than I would expect. You don't actually make the llama plushy. It comes already sewn. You sew on the face (more difficult since the plush is already sewn), stuff the body, and sew up a small hole. Kids really are capable of hand sewing a small plush. Other than it being sewn already, the set itself is cute and kid's will have fun playing with it after. This is a very beginner project. I have kids ranging from newborn to 11 years old. This seemed most ideal for my 6 year old.

title: Fun
text: I was hesitant about these, because I was concerned about them getting tangled in hair and such like those fiendish Bunchems. However, these are the old school style bristle blocks. They are really easy for little hands to put together. My kids really like them and the toddler finds them easy to work with.

title: Magic!
text: This is a good kid's magic set. Like all magic sets I have ever come across, not everything is super high quality. But in the world of novelty illusions, that is really to be expected. It comes with lots of tricks for the kids to try and work at mastering.

title: Preschool Fun
text: The colors of these beads are so fun. This is fun for preschool and younger elementary kids. They can work on their pattern making skills and their fine motor skills. The beads pop together and pop apart, so you can make and remake over and over. There are some bangle type bracelets included, as well. They are small, so they would not be appropraite for kids under 3 or preschoolers who still put stuff in their mouths. The reusable bucket gives you a place to store them when you aren't playing with them.

title: Awesome Robot
text: Build your own robot! And this robot is pretty cool. He reminds me of Wall-E. My 10 year old can build this set entirely by himself using the instructions. You do need batteries. But everything else you need is in the box. Build him and then play with him.

title: Toddler Fun
text: Put the block in front of Scout and Scout will "read" the block. My toddler thinks this is great fun. It is loud and annoying, but he laughs so much with it, I'll deal with the talking toy.

title: Robot Arms
text: This is a really neat set. The parts are plastic, for the most part. It comes with a book to explain how to put the different models together with the provided pieces and how they work. My 10 year old is very into robotics and building things. This has been right up his alley. He loves it. It is definitely not for little kids with all the tiny pieces. But older elementary kids and up should be able to use this and understand what they are doing. I really love that this is more than a toy. Yes, they are making things to play around with, but they are learning a lot while doing it.

title: Go To Sleep
text: This is a very basic game for older toddlers and younger preschoolers. Older kids will be bored to tears. There aren't very many parts to lose, so that is good. You place the animals around the barn awake and put them to sleep in the barn. The rooster wakes animals back up. You play until all the animals, except the rooster are sleeping. You can do the animal noises as you play, which makes it more fun for the kids. It also helps the younger ones learn about taking turns and following directions.

title: Fun and Portable
text: This toy is relatively simple. You press the little semi-circle button and the square above it pops up. It is a lot of fun for toddlers and preschoolers who love pressing buttons. You really have to play with them for it to actually be educational. It is a good portable toy, if you are looking for something to take to grandma's or something. My only real issue with this toy is the quality. The letters, shapes, and such are all stickers on plastic. They are glossy stickers and some of them are just hastily placed and don't look nice and neat. Although, you could customize the whole thing by adding new 1/2" square stickers over the existing stickers.

title: Colorful Blocks
text: This is a really fun colored wagon of blocks. The kids love building with the blocks (which are Lego Duplo like) and pulling the wagon around. I love that there is a place to store the blocks when they aren't in use. There are a couple special blocks, with wheels and little hooks to connect like trains. I love the colors.

title: Dinosaur Fun
text: My kids had a blast with this. Each egg is individually packaged with a little tool to help dig the dinosaur out. The consistency of the eggs is like chalk. Things will get messy and dusty. But it is so much fun!

title: Amazing Symphony
text: This toy makes noise. It is really the point of the toy. I'm not usually a big fan of noisy plastic toys, but my 2 year old is in LOVE with this thing. He sits and changes out the instruments and dances to the music. He is just amazed by this. And the noise isn't too awful, since it is at least music.

title: Massive!
text: This is the most ridiculously extreme Imaginext set I have ever seen. This thing is massive! My 6 year old is the biggest Batman fan. He was completely floored when he laid eyes on this thing. It is so big! It is a lot of fun. This is over 2 feet tall. It does require batteries. The little Imaginext figures can fit inside the Batbot. It does have small parts and little projectiles, but the kids have SO much fun with this guy.

title: Retro Diner
text: This is an adorable little kitchen. One side is a little kitchen and the other side is a table. It is perfect! Every kid immediately starts playing restaurant when they hit a play kitchen, this one is just already set for it! The wood is like a particle board type stuff. It is heavy. This is well made. It is very comparable in quality to our previous KidKraft kitchens. Plus the retro design is adorable! It is a little more awkward to find a place for it, since it is double sided. But, you can put a "side" along a wall or just pull it a couple feet away from a wall and you are good to go. Because of the design, it does take up a little more room than a standard play kitchen. But it also provides a sitting area.

title: Great Set
text: My kids are big fans of building blocks and they love Despicable Me, so this set was a win for them. They work with all their other building sets. They were easily able to put the kit together on their own with no adult help. (They are 10, 8, and 6. Well, the ones who play with these blocks most are.) The little people are different than the ones you get with *the other guys* sets, but they are cute and likeable.

title: Huge Spider
text: My 8 and 10 year olds love these Meccano sets. This one has been a big hit. It is really big. The instructions are clear enough that they can follow them and build the set without help from me or my husband. There are a lot of small parts, so this is definitely not for little kids. And my 6 year old would never be able to build it by himself. Lots of fun, and just a little bit on the creepy side- being a huge robotic spider. It does require batteries.

title: Ponies
text: This is such a cute game. It is set up like Candy Land and played like Candy Land, but none of the Candy Land characters are part of it. Just My Little Pony characters. The actual game pieces are ponies. The board has ponies on it instead of Candy Land characters. It is very cute and fun for little ones.

title: Batman Command Center
text: My boys love Imaginext. They graduate from the Little People to Imaginext. They have several Imaginext sets, including the Bat Cave thing and several of the Batman bad guy sets. This particular set is more magical than those. It is an RC car and an Imaginext toy all in one. It is a little boy's dream come true! If you have a little Batman fan in your life, this would make an amazing gift. My boys, especially my 6 year old, LOVE this toy. He'd probably choose this over his Bat Cave any day.

title: Fun!
text: My preschooler loves this toy. My toddler is also constantly trying to steal it from him. It is for fun, I wouldn't say it is actual school or anything. But they love playing with this book and I do think they are learning some as they play, which is really ideal for that age. It isn't as annoying as other toys that make noise. (You know the ones, you "loose" the batteries after a week of hearing it.) They love this toy.

title: Not Durable
text: This is really cute. I love the way it looks. However, it is not durable at all. The whole thing is made of cardboard. Babies and toddler chew on things. Chewing on cardboard, well, it makes the cardboard fall apart eventually, even if it is really well made cardboard. The box does open from the top. And again, super cute, just not durable at all.

title: Love
text: My boys love Imaginext toys. I love this one. We actually used it while reading some historical fiction about ancient Egypt. The kids thought it was fun to have their own pyramid. Definitely made for some more interesting play. Great for toddlers on through 10 year olds.

title: Logic Skills
text: This is a single player game, not a group thing. I have several other games that are similar in the way they work. You have a card with a roller coaster on it. You use the available pieces to replicate that coaster with nothing but the image of the finished coaster. It is great for logic and problem solving abilities. If you want to add a group element, you can always time how long it takes for each person to build the coaster. It has small pieces. The kids think it is fun and they are learning while playing, so I'm happy.

title: Fun
text: This is a small set. It says ages 5-10, but a 5 year old doesn't usually have the logic capabilities to follow directions to put things together. But they can make a variety of vehicles. The curved pieces aren't curved in the box, they are straight and are curved by connecting them to the various holding pieces. My kids love it and think K'NEX are really fun.

title: Go!
text: My kids LOVE Imaginext sets. They went from the Fisher Price Little People to the Imaginext. This particular set has been a great set for the little kids and big kids to play together. My 2, 4, 6, 8, and 9 year olds all love this set. The pictures show all the Titans, but it only comes with Robin and the Mammoth character and the pig. The other Titans have to be purchased separately.

title: Great Set
text: Imaginext play sets are awesome. My boys love them. This Arkham Asylum only comes with Batman. (It really should come with only villains, but it doesn't come with any.) This is a great addition to any Imaginext collection. Kids LOVE Batman. Kids LOVE Imaginext. That makes this an easy win-win. My 2,4,6, and 8 year old boys all love this playset.

title: A Hit, As Always
text: Imaginext sets are always a hit in my house. Batman is always a hit in my house. We have quite a few Imaginext Batman figures now, which is actually a good thing so they aren't fighting over who gets to be Batman. This is perfect to go with the Batcave and other Imaginext sets we have. My 4, 6, and 8 year olds all love this.

title: Very Cool Kid Watch
text: This watch was extremely easy to set up. You can use it right out of the box before syncing it with your computer. All the apps and things are loaded on the watch already. My 7 year old was able to figure out and navigate the interface without any troubles. He thinks this is the most amazing watch ever. It will adjust small enough to fit my very small 4 year old, as well. It does have a main power switch on the back. Every time you flip that, you'll have to reset the date and time. It plugs into your computer and can charge from there and upload pictures and sound clips to your computer. Or you can charge it using a wall outlet. The charger is the same that is on a Kindle. It is a lot of fun figuring out what the watch will do. Plus, you can set timers for when they need to come inside or whatever.

title: Epic
text: This is an epic float. It it huge. It did take me about 20 minutes to pump up with the manual pump. It would have been much quicker with an electric air compressor. The cover has vents to let the water out, so it doesn't sit in there and mold or mildew. The headrest isn't very comfortable. It is too far up on the float. But it moves, so it isn't a problem. It is really tall. You have to be in the center to not flip it. Two people trying to sit side by side will easily flip it. But one person in the center is stable enough. It has pockets on the ide for a drink or whatever. It is really heavy. So, carrying it around is a bit of a challenge. The float part is actually two parts to pump up. It works well as a side of pool lounger or a float.

title: Slightly Terrifying
text: This squirrel is a little on the terrifying side, rather than the cute side. Your hand fits inside very awkwardly. It feels more like an empty stuffed animal than an actual puppet. But it is soft. And it is fun to use for story time. The bushy tail is attached to the back of the puppet. You have to fluff him up a bit to be able to see his ears and such.

title: Fun and Fuzzy
text: This is such a fun puzzle for little guys! My 2 and 4 year olds LOVE it. It has 20 really large, sturdy pieces. There are several different tactile elements on the puzzle. Most of them are soft or fuzzy. You have a shiny whale tail, a furry deer, a fuzzy baby bear, a soft penguin belly, and a rough and shiny fish belly. The puzzle is fun to put together. It also has a large poster that you can use as a puzzle mat to help guide where the pieces go, or just to look at for reference. This is a large puzzle. Very fun!

title: So Much Fun
text: My boys thought this was the most fun ever. Apparently finding out what is inside your geode is as fun as opening mystery packs! The hammer isn't included. Just the rocks, a tiny plastic magnifying glass, and a couple thick plastic bags. Breaking the geodes in the bag didn't work and they resorted to just hammering at the geode directly, which worked. Some were tougher to break than others, but that was part of the fun. They really liked using the included booklet to figure out which geodes they found. This was a fun activity that was both physical and educational.

title: Cute, but Not Sturdy
text: This little drum is so cute. Unfortunately, it is not very sturdy. The drum part separates easily from the bear. I cannot seem to get the two to stay together. It seems they were just pressure fit. Which is a bummer because it was such a cute little drum.

title: Heavy Duty
text: We love this little camera. You look through the prism, which makes for some interesting sights. You can also spin the prism while you look through it, which creates really interesting kaleidoscope effects. It has a little button so they can pretend to take pictures, it is so basic, but such a fun toy for little ones. It is very sturdy, so if you're toddler or baby happens to be a thrower, you may want to avoid this one, because it can cause some damage, I appreciate the durability as my little guys take it outside all the time to "take pictures" of plants and dirt. It gets dropped often, but still looks great and is holding up to their rougher play.

title: Adorably Squishy
text: This doll is adorable. They did miss an opportunity by not making it smell like strawberries, but it is really adorable. The hat is removable. It does have a small bit of velcro in the top underside of the hat, so it sticks to Baby Stella's hair. This baby has brown hair and brown eyes. The little strawberry sack comes off and you have a baby in white pajamas with green spots. (The pajamas are not removable, but the strawberry bag is.) The strawberry bag is stitched to the back of Baby Stella. You can leave it tacked on or snip the stitch to make it completely removable. My kids think it looks more like a tomato than a strawberry. It is the perfect size for little hands. This is the size my 2 year old prefers. The polyester velour on the outside is very soft and cuddly. This product is made in China, if that matters to you.

title: Great for Motor Skills
text: My two, three, and five year olds love this little board. They are busy little guys and they have had so much fun with the latching and unlatching. The little latches work very smoothly. Doors open and close smoothly. Some of the latches might be too difficult for younger skills, but it is a great way to practice motor skills. Also, none of the pieces come off, so there is absolutely nothing to lose. (Much to the relief of this mom who is forever fighting the losing battle of lost puzzle pieces.) The little animals are all adorable, and the color matched their door.

title: Adorable
text:
This scooter is seriously adorable! It comes in a box with a carrying handle. It comes in 4 pieces and includes the tools needed for assembly. I needed 2 adults to put it together, just because putting the pieces together with wheels on the pieces proved to be a littl difficult on my own. With a second adult to help, it went together in about 5 minutes. The instructions are very minimal, with no words, and unfortunately, not much detail. But it was easy enough to figure it out. The wheels do air up. They have regular bike tire spouts on them. The handle bars have a rubbery grip on them. The seat does adjust up higher as they grow. As it is, my two year old (who is tiny- wears 18 month clothes and weighs 24 lbs.) is a little short for the scooter. However, my 3 and 5 year olds can ride it very easily.
There were a couple places on the scooter where the wood was split or chipped. It doesn't effect the ride or overall look, but it is a tiny bit of a bummer. However, those are really defects I would expect in a product like this made out of wood.
Overall, I love it. It is a very fun balance bike and will fit him for years to come.

title: So Fun!
text: These Janod puzzles are really nice. It comes in a reusable box that sits on the shelf easily and has a carrying handle and lock. It also comes with a full size poster of the puzzle that you can use as a guide, or as a mat under the puzzle to make it easier to put together. The pieces are really thick and durable. This is a great puzzle!

title: Adorable Boxes
text: My 2 year old and 4 year old think these are amazing. The come in an adorable box with a cloth handle that is perfect for gift giving. The boxes are nestled into each other, so they really don't take up much space. There are 10 boxes total. They are all made out of a durable feeling cardboard with paper covering. They won't last forever, being cardboard, but they are light weight and fun. Kids can easily pick them up and handle them and when the tower falls it doesn't hurt anyone or anything. Each box has one side open except for box 10, which is not as thick as the others, but it a tiny cube. They are sized to stack easily, even if you don't get them perfectly lined up. Little hands have no problem stacking and unstacking. The little animals pictures are adorable and I love the muted color palette.

title: Animals!
text: This is a great toy. It is like a set of 16 one-piece puzzles. Each of the backgrounds is double sided. The animals are only painted in detail on one side. (The side that faces up.) My 2 year old and almost 4 year old have sat and played with this for hours. Matching the animals with the habitat, making up stories about the animals, making animal sounds, over and over. It is very cute. The pieces are painted wood. This is similar to the Melissa and Doug puzzles. The paint isn't exactly paint, it is like a Jamberry on painted wood. If that makes sense. They are sturdy and good quality. And it comes with a handy little wooden tray for storage. The set comes with: shark, dolphin, octopus, brown bear, fox, deer, sheep, pig, cow, giraffe, lion, zebra, horse, sea turtle, elephant, and raccoon.

title: Walk!
text: My 2 year old was ecstatic to play with this stroller. It can be a single stroller, double stroller, backpack, or car seat for your baby doll. It is a little big for my 2 year old. It is sized more for my 4 and 6 year olds. It is versatile, and fun for pretend play. It was very easy to put together. Just open it up and pop on the front wheels. Very simple. It does fold flat. And it is very light weight. A toddler can easily lift it without problems.

title: Build and Rebuild A Robot Pet
text: With this kit, your child can build one of several robots. They can even take it apart and build something else. The robots move around after you build them. A simple button on the torso plate operates it. This requires no tools. You will need 2 AA batteries, which are not included. My 9 year old and his friends loved putting this robot together again and again. It was simple enough for them to do without adult help at all.

title: *High Pitch Noises*
text: My 3 year old loves Dr. Who. He was so happy to get his very own Sonic Screwdriver. He absolutely loves it. It lights up. It makes noises. It opens. Now, my issues are this. One of the buttons never works when it is closed. It should, but the parts don't quite line up correctly. It also comes apart. It is designed to, so it goes back together easily. But it comes apart too easily. It should be harder to do than it is. It is harder to put back together than it is to get apart.

title: No
text: My 2 year old's favorite word is no, so my daughter thought it would be funny to get him this cat and a Grumpy Cat book as a gift. His joy at opening this grumpy kitty was so funny. He loves it. He hugs it a squeezes it, which is funny, because the cat always looks like he is protesting the massive amounts of affection.

title: Great Joker
text: My Batman crazy son loved this tank! He loves that the cannon shoots the little punching hand. He has the BatCave, so he likes to make Joker and Batman battle it out. He absolutely loves the Imaginext toys. (He is 5.) This Joker more resembles the Batman movies of the 90s.

title: He Loves It
text: I have one dinosaur crazy son and one Batman crazy son. They love the Imaginext figures because they can play together with their favorite things, but everything "goes" together. I know it sounds a little crazy to have a raptor in a BatCave, but that is how they play. This little dinosaur and his man are a big hit with my dinosaur lover.

title: Cinder
text: They really need more mythical Beanie Boos. My kids absolutely love Beanie Boos. The eyes are just irresistible. Cinder has an iridescent scale pattern on his body with shiny shimmery purple accents. He is really cute.

title: BatBear!
text: BatBear is so adorable. My 5 year old is obsessed with Batman. He has a stuffed Batman bear from Build A Bear, but this bear is already dressed like Batman! (As opposed to the BAB Batman Bear that is a bear with a bat symbol print on the bear.) I like that his costume does not come off. It makes it much easier to keep BatBear looking like BatBear. I also really like that he is the old school Batman, not the newer one. He is super soft and squishy.

title: Fun!
text: My kids absolutely love the Funko Pop characters. They already had several in the Doctor Who set, so the twelfth doctor was a huge hit. They do not use them like collectables, but rather like action figures, which is completely fine with me. They stage battles between multiple doctors and daleks, weeping angels, and such. They don't move like a traditional action figure, but they are really durable.

title: Loves It
text: The charger on this thing is weird. But other than that, my nine year old has loved thing. He has had other RC planes and cars in the past, but this is kind of a two in one. He can ramp it off the curb and it takes flight. The battery charge doesn't really last all that long.

title: Wooden Ark
text: The animals and such are quite small, but we have really enjoyed this set. Very similar to the Janod wooden toys. The top of the ark comes off for easy storage and retrieval of the animals.

title: Arlo and His Critter
text: This is a really large set. The Arlo is huge! My 3 year old is in love with these. They are very well made. They are a little on the overstuffed side, so they are more rigid than soft and squishy. Don't get me wrong, they are still plushies. But they are very stuffed plushies, so they hold their shape well and even stand on their own.

title: They Love It
text: My toddler is super into dinosaurs. His older brother is super into Imaginext. This gives them the opportunity to play together. The ball isn't attached to the dinosaur. The little person can ride the dinosaur. The kids love it.

title: Pretend Play
text: I'm new to Playmobile. Not sure how we have never had these type of toys before. My kids love this set. It has small pieces, so it is best to keep it away from babies. But my 3, 5, and 7 year olds love it. The 9 and 10 year old like playing with it with their younger siblings, but not on their own. Great pretend play opportunities.

title: Food Truck for Mini Foodies
text: This is an adorable play kitchen for a young toddler. It has the mega blocks component, which is a fun addition. It is a great size for around 18 months to 3 years old. Older than that and they would likely do better with a full kitchen. Though my older kids do like to help the toddlers with this one.

title: Fun!
text: My son that adores Hot Wheels is getting older. He still loves Hot Wheels, but I am always looking for something a little more epic. Enter this doohickey! He can make his own cars! They aren't really the same as his other cars. These are not full metal. But this is so much fun. He loves it. It is on the heavy side. Just be warned about that bit. The cars themselves aren't the highest quality, but they are fun for him to make. He likes to display the cars he made, not race them.

title: Cute Doll
text: Such a cute little doll! Its little bunny suit is removable, which I like because kids for whatever reason like dressing and undressing dolls. But this one is still dressed when you take the bunny suit off. Underneath, it is wearing orange stripey pajamas with turquoise trim. Those clothes are not removable. The hair is sewn into place, it is not loose at all. There is no ponytail or pigtails. Just the little swirl in the front. This is a suitable doll for boys and girls of all ages. Its cute little face is very neutral and relaxed. Another great product by Manhattan Toy.

title: Adorable
text: Clover is so adorable. I could do without the extra blocks, just one more thing to loose until you step on it at 3am. Really, where this toy shines is on the non-shape sorter side. There is a little abacus type action going on over there that my toddler just loves. Pull Clover around. Push clover around. Hang out and play. Lots of opportunities for movement and exploration. Plus, how adorable is this thing?

title: Big Hit
text: This truck is so much bigger than I expected. It is definitely a two handed toy. The holes make it easy for clumsy little hands to grab and play with. Both my 18 month old and my 3 year old love it!

title: Perfect
text: Such a cute wristlet. My tween loves it! (Though it would be appropriate for smaller kids, too.) The back of the bag is solid oink canvas. The pink on the front is glittery. So much fun to color. Even more fun to keep! It is like two gifts in one!

title: Exciting Set
text:
Based on quality, I would give this set 3 stars. You get a clay "rock" with hidden gems. The supplies are really cheap. The brush is a cheap paintbrush that comes in grade school watercolor sets. The package is just a plastic clam shell pack. So, based on that, I'd give it three stars.
However, my kids would give it 5 stars. They love it. It was a super exciting introduction to gems and stones for them. They could not have been more thrilled about it.
So, I'll average the two and give it 4 stars. Don't expect extraordinary quality. But the kids do love it and think it is ridiculously awesome. I mean, maybe that is all that really counts. The pure excitement.

title: Love This Wagon!
text: This is the ease of a stroller for packing with the fun of a wagon for riding. My toddlers prefer a wagon many places. Places like the zoo are much easier with a wagon. However, the problem had always been packing a standard wagon into the van. The stroller just folds up easier. Enter this wagon! Now we can have the ease of packing with a wagon! Your kids have to be old enough to ride in a wagon. I find around 11 months mine usually can. Might be sooner or later for your child.

title: Great
text: Kid Kraft makes the best play kitchens, in my opinion. They are just built to last. This one is great and takes up less space than our previous play kitchen due to the corner design. My kids love it. If you are looking for a play kitchen, definitely go Kid Kraft.

title: Love It
text: The jar part itself is nothing all that special. Just a plastic jar. About the feel of a plastic water bottle. The lid is where the magic is. The handle goes on and off. The top is magnifying and has holes. It also fits a standard size jar. So, should you find that the plastic jar isn't up to the task, you can stick it on a regular sized mouth jar. (Not wide mouth.) My kids love looking for bugs and holding them temporarily to watch them. You can even put small critters in the jar (lizards, snails, crabs) or small fish since the jar itself is solid.

title: Great Set
text: My 9 year old son loved this set! It even makes noise! He finds the Mega blocks sets a little more challenging than the other name brand. His 7 and 5 year old brothers were more than happy to help him with assembly. Great set.

title: Tank
text: A pretty complex set to put together. Definitely not a build in 15 minutes and then forget it kind of set. (Which is good in my world.) My boys loved it. They thought it was great. These style of blocks fit together with other blocks of this size so you won't have multiple types of blocks messing everything up. The camp colors added a challenge to building the tank.

title: Travel Harry Potter Trivia
text: This is a mini version of Trivial Pursuit with only Harry Potter questions. No board. Just cards, colored die, and the triangle box. My kids love it.

title: Cute Owl
text: She loves this little owl. He is very soft and cozy. And super cute.

title: Fantastic Barapasaurus
text: This barapasaurus is really big. He fits well with the other Schleich dinosaurs we have. This one is pretty heavy, due to his size. He also seems to be a slightly harder plastic than the t-rex or raptor versions we have. He also has a non-movable mouth. Some of the newer Schleich dinos have movable mandibles, but this guy does not. He has a lot of great details and the kids think he is fantastic. As usual, great quality toy from Schleich.

title: Adipose
text: This cute little guy was a hit with my kids. They adore these little Funko  figures. The detailing is great.

title: Roar!
text: Schleich toys are such good quality toys. This T-Rex has a movable mandible. He is very sturdy and is bigger than the other Schleich dinosaurs. (Because he should be bigger.) He is in a semi crouched position, standing about 6" tall and 12" from tale to nose. The detailing on these things is just insane. My kids love these as do all kid visitors in our house. The Schleich basket is often the go-to toy around here. He is quite solid. Big enough to be fun, small enough for little hands to play with. We have another Schleich T-Rex with the movable mandible and while I was initially nervous about the moving parts not lasting, he is holding strong after a year of very heavy use.

title: Not Fun
text: The idea behind this is good. The execution is not so good. I tried this product with my 6, 8, and 9 year olds. They could not get the thing to work well for them. You put cardboard cut outs on a plastic vase or bowl. Then you use a syringe/pen thing full of slightly thinner playdoh to decorate the plastic and cardboard vase or bowl while it spins on a little turntable. First, it is hard to get the playdoh to come out in even streams to make a design. It is difficult not the knock over the very lightweight vase or bowl while you are decorating. And then once you do manage to get the things decorated, what on earth are you going to do with them? They are lightweight plastic and cardboard and playdoh. Not exactly fit for keeping around. It was very frustrating for the kids. And not all that much pay off for the work you put in.

title: Not Quite As Pictured
text: Item was a little darker than pictured. You couldn't really see the lines inside the leaf, it was more of just a dark green blob. It also came with a chain to wear as a necklace. Not the highest quality, but as good as I would have expected for the price.

title: Very Small Drum
text: This drum is tiny. Even smaller than I expected. I purchased it for a baby, because what baby doesn't need a baby sized djembe? But it is really, really small. 4.5" is not quite correct. It is 4.5" from the outer ropes across. The actual drum head is more like 3.5". But it is really well made. It even sounds good, which surprised me with its tiny size. The drum head on mine was a little rippled. It came in a box, so it was easy to wrap. It makes a cute gift or a neat little drum to sit out on your coffee table.

title: Fantastic T-Rex
text: This is one sturdy T-Rex. My toddler loves dinosaurs. Cartoonish versions simply will not do. They have to look real. This T-Rex looks real. It is very sturdy and a little on the heavy side. His skin is textured and he is mid-roar. This is a very cool toy. Much bigger than other versions he has received. But when placed with other Schleich dinosaurs, he is appropriately sized! The raptors are small, the T-Rex is big. Makes sense. And my toddler loves him!

title: Cute Snail
text: This is a cute pull along snail. It is wooden. The connector for the eyes is like rubber tubes, so the eyes move about. The snail's shell just sets on top of the wheel base. This makes it really impossible for a baby to use the whole thing. They can use the shell to put the blocks in and out, but they completely lack the motor skills to prop the shell onto the base. I actually found it a little weird to get the shell on. And as soon as you bump the side of the snail, you knock the shell loose. So, this gets pulled around shellless while the shell sits around being used as a shape sorter. I very much wish it hadn't been multifunctional, so the baby could enjoy it in full. The wood seems to be decent quality. No paint chipping issues yet, despite rabid baby chewing. So, well built, but functionally flawed.

title: Fun For Many Ages
text: This is really a good product for younger kids and indoor use. It really is. My only real issue is the quality. Foam kid products just always end up being a bad idea. They tear up so easily. For some reason, the handlebar is constantly being taken off of this and used as a weapon. The unicorn head is foam and is somewhat in the way when jumping. I just wish it were anything but foam. With a toddler in the house, we've already had a few bites taken out of this thing, despite my best efforts to make the kids put it up. It is fun. Hop on in anywhere. It squeaks when you hop. No weight limit. Even the toddler manages to hop a few times.  My kids (2, 4, 5, 7, and 9) all like hopping around on this jumper. (We actually have 3 of these Pogo Jumpers. 2 of the primary color ones and one unicorn.)

title: Three Streams
text: This isn't a super high powered super soaker. It is a small water gun. She thinks it is fun and loves it. She also thinks it is great that it shoots 3 streams of water. This water gun is easy enough for my 4 year old to use. It is on the small side and requires frequent refilling. Overall, we're happy with this water gun.

title: Gun and Holster
text: My 8 year old daughter love the Nerf Rebelle products. This gun and holsters fits into her collection really well. Ours only came with 4 darts, not 8 as shown. It works by pulling the hammer on the back (which is much easier for smaller hands than the cocking mechanism of other Nerf guns). It only shoots one dart at a time, the darts do not rotate, they just fire one at a time from the four holes. A good addition to your Nerf arsenal.

title: Easy and Fun
text: My 8 year old daughter loves the Nerf Rebelle line! She loved this little sling shot. It required assembly, which was a little strange since most Nerf products come fully put together. It did take us a couple minutes of fiddling with the thing to realize where exactly the bullet needed to go. It comes with two bullets, or darts, whatever you call them. Pull the string back, shoot. Easy and fun.

title: Great Set
text: This track set is lots of fun. We have several other buider tracks, and this one makes a nice addition to the ones we have. Just good fun for kids. I find that 5 is really the youngest age they can play with these sets independently, and even then, it may take an older kid or adult showing them how it works first. The younger ones enjoy watching the cars go around but cannot manage to play alone. They always end up knocking pieces of track down.

title: Good Cards
text: Good set, especially for those just getting started collecting. There were a few duplicates, but I would expect that in a bulk batch.

title: Great Size
text: My 8 year old daughter suddenly decided she wanted to collect Pokemon cards. We got her this small book to hold them, so it wouldn't look completely empty. (She has 50 cards.) The description says it will hold 40 cards, but it will actually hold 80. (2 cards per pocket, one facing each direction.) She loves it. It is small enough to carry around in her bag, but big enough that she feels like she has plenty of cards. And she still has room for some more cards. The pages are made into the book, so you cannot add more pages. We'll likely repurchase this when she fills the first one up, because the size is so much more usable for a kid than the large 3 ring binder style. My 5 and 7 year olds now want their own, as well.

title: Wonderful Robots
text: This toy is absolutely wonderful. My three year old LOVES robots. We have a few of the Janod sets, and while I like them, they are pretty small. The pieces of these robot magnets are not small, though. They are appropriate for a younger child. These are easy enough for my 19 month old to put together and play with. We also love that the box is durable enough to keep and store the pieces in when not in use. My 3 year old and 19 month old LOVE these. My 5 year old even loves playing with them. They are a little simple/childish for my 7 and 8 year olds.

title: My Kids Loves Them
text: My 5 year old is obsessed with Lego Hero Factory. They aren't your typical Legos. More like Lego and Kinex had a baby and Hero Factory was born. The Hero Factory sets all work together, but they don't work with regular Legos. My son loves them. He builds the Hero straight out of the pack using the simple directions. Then he'll eventually dump all the pieces into his Lego Hero Factory box and make his own versions of Heros.

title: Good Set
text: My 5 year old is a big fan of the Lego Hero Factory sets. He has had his eye on this set in particular for months. He has been thrilled with it.

title: Could Love It More
text:
My kids love this box set. They love the circus characters and find it very fun. I was a little surprised with the size of the pieces. They are small. Choking hazard small. The warning isn't a joke- the people are tiny. I'm also not very impressed with the quality of the box. It is cardboard, and while slightly heavier duty than most toy boxes, it really doesn't hold up well. The box had to be taped back together the first day after my 5 year old stepped on it.
It is a cute toy, I would just like to see the pieces slightly larger and the box more durable, since it is a part of the set.

title: Very Cute Set
text: My 18 month old, 3 year old, 5 year old, and 7 year old all love this little ship. The pirates and treasure chest come sewn on (small tacking), which is common for Manhattan Toys, so you'll have to snip the set apart. The ship opens on the deck and the pirates and their treasure can go inside. The little map is quite detailed, but I had to remove it from the set because it was so small. The entire ship and pirates are plush. The arch the sail hangs on makes a great handle for carrying around. The anchor is attached to the boat with a small ribbon. My kids love this pirate ship!

title: Darts!
text: This refill dart pack was exactly what we needed. The darts fit all her Nerf Rebelle guns. Some of the darts were solid colors. Some of the darks were patterned.

title: Good Weapon
text: This is a good Nerf gun. It comes with the blue and orange darts. The Nerf works by pulling back the top grey sheath. (This mechanism of action is more difficult for younger kids. The hammer action weapons are easier for smaller kids.) The gun is quite large, but not too big to run around with. The dart chamber slides out sideways to refill. That seems to be more for novelty than necessity, but the boys all think that is cool.

title: Cute!!!
text: This was my 3 year old son's favorite gift this Christmas. The little kittens have magnetic noses that stick to the Mama Cat's nipples. (Circles on the under side of the cat.) The kittens are small, about 5.5" from tail to nose. They have little whiskers. The Mama and Kittens are very soft and have some beads inside for some added weight. My 18 month old, 5 year old, 7 year old, and 8 year old were all jealous of this gift. Now they all want one!

title: Soft and Sweet
text: My 3 year old begged for this doll. I'm not sure what he found so appealing, but he thinks it is awesome. The doll has a cloth diaper that velcros on and off. The clothes do come off. The little paci has a magnet in it and sticks to the baby's face that way. It has little joints and digits sewn in. It is a very well made doll. The cloth is very soft and the doll is very cuddly. And it is sturdy enough for a 3 year old boy who sometimes abuses his poor baby. I'm very happy with this doll.

title: Great Hopper
text: I was a little nervous this would be huge for my 18 month old. It isn't. It is the perfect height for him to straddle with both feet on the floor. (My 3 and 5 year old also seem to fit. It is way too small for my 7 year old, though.) This is a very sturdy hopper. (We have had quite a few through the years and this is the thickest ones we've had.) It looks more like a donkey than a horse. It isn't shiny plastic like other hoppers we have had. It is very stable, too. Yes, the 3 and 5 year old flip it over. But the 18 month old easily bounces in place without falling over.

title: Good Weapon
text: This Nerf gun comes with the bright green zombie darts. It has a holster, so the weapon can be put on the kid's hip. It works by pulling back the sheath on top of the gun. (This mechanism can be difficult for younger kids. The hammer style are easier for younger ones.) My son loves this gun. It isn't tiny, but is also compact and easily carried around.

title: Good Weapon
text: This Nerf gun works with pulling back the hammer and then pulling the trigger. The darts are bright green. My 7 year old loves it. The darts fly far enough to get one stuck on the roof of our house (2 stories up). It is compact, but not tiny.

title: Sweet Babies
text: These were a gift for my 18 month old. He is in the take things out, put things in stage. He loves these babies. He takes them out of the pod. He puts them back in the pod. He's also been into babies recently, so this toy has been perfect for him. The babies come tacked into the pod, so you'll have to cut them out. (This is pretty standard for Manhattan Toys.) The inside of the pod is silky, so the babies slip in and out. The babies have two pieces of ribbon for hair, so it isn't too gross if a younger one chews on it. Overall, a great toy. Even my older kids like to pick it up and play. (They are 8, 7, 5, and 3.)

title: Not As Great As I Hoped
text: I loved the idea of these box sets. This was a gift for my 3 year old. I had anticipated my 18 month old getting to play with it, as well, but the pieces are far too small for him. Many are definitely a choking hazard. The pieces are wooden, but aren't as sturdy as they could be. (The farmer's wife's head got broken off during the first time my 3 and 5 year old played with it. I glued it back, but will likely have to trash it if they break it again.) The box itself is cardboard. It is thicker and should be durable, but had to be taped after the first day of use. (My 5 year old can be very rough on toys. He is the durability test of all toys for sure.) I thought the box would be sturdier. Overall, it is a cute toy, but the size and durability took me by surprise a little. I expect wood toys to be more durable.

title: Fun!
text: My boys got these for indoor jumping and regular pogo sticks for outdoor jumping. These are so much easier for them to use than the regular pogo sticks. They squeak when they jump, so that is a little annoying to me. But the kids love them. (They are 3, 5, and 7.) This stick fits kids of all sizes. My 3 year old and 7 year old can use the same jumper. Adults can even jump. A great pogo to begin with or use to jump indoors.

title: Doll Horse
text: My 8 year old daughter loves this horse with her Groovy Girl dolls. The dolls fit in the saddle easily. The hair is yarn, the same as the Groovy Girls. It is on the large size. About the size of 2 Groovy Girls. The hair is not really brushable, but also doesn't get nasty like regular doll hair. My daughter is very happy with this toy.

title: Fuzzy Soft
text: These are fairly small, which is perfect since they were a gift for my 18 month old. They can hug other Sesame Street hug dolls or they can hug a kid's arm. They aren't big enough to hug around them. The arms kind of feel like old school slap bracelets are inside. These are fuzzy soft and toddler friendly.

title: Fuzzy Hugs
text: These are fairly small, which is perfect since they were a gift for my 18 month old. They can hug other Sesame Street hug dolls or they can hug a kid's arm. They aren't big enough to hug around them. The arms kind of feel like old school slap bracelets are inside. These are fuzzy soft and toddler friendly.

title: Creative Fun
text:
This is a very cute book for tweens. All the models pictured are girls. The models all look like tween girls, stylized with anime style eyes and lips. There are stencils and stickers to design the blank shirt pages. Some of the shirts are tanks, some are tees, some are longer sleeved dolmans. This does not come with colored pencils or markers. However, that is not a problem for us since my 8 year old has oodles of high quality colored pencils to choose from.
This book is JUST decorating t-shirts on paper. It does not translate to a real life shirt. It is not a "how to" on customizing a plain tee. It is essentially a coloring book for tweens.

title: Great Fun
text: My 8 year old and 7 year old are Rainbow Loom crazy. This is the second one I have purchased for them. They make bracelets, necklaces, charms, people, clothing for dolls, etc. All with rubber bands and a loom. My 8 year old prefers to use a metal crochet hook instead of the provided hook. My 5 year old doesn't have the manual dexterity for the loom yet. I'm sure he'll get involved in the looming once he can manage.

title: Great Set
text: This is a great set. It comes with a holster that just slips over the top of pants or a belt. (Only have issues when she is wearing a dress and can't find a spot for her holster.) The glasses make them feel extra cool as they strut the neighborhood. The gun comes with the designer Nerf Rebelle darts, but works with any standard Nerf dart. You pull the hammer back and then pull the trigger to shoot. The holster also holds extra darts.

title: Fun!
text: My daughter loves this bow. She carries it around all the time! It shoots Nerf darts. It comes with the Rebelle designer darts, but any standard Nerf darts fit. We did have an issue with it cracking after she dropped it out of a tree, but a little silicone caulk fixed it and it still works exactly the same.

title: Awesome Set
text:
This block set is awesome! I was a little nervous, because all my kid's building blocks are *the other brand*. I wasn't sure if they'd all work together and I hate having multiple clock systems. These work just fine with *the other brand*. I know I looked it up before hand and read that blocks were of different sizes and therefore you couldn't build with them. But have you seen the number of specialty blocks around? You could easily say that about just *the other brand*. The blocks do click together, though, which was my main concern.
I'm not sure how accurate it is to Call of Duty. My kids aren't into that game, they're just into zombies. As a zombie set, this one is awesome.

title: Bright and Lively Ride On Toy
text:
My 15 month old loves this toy! It is shaped a little differently from other sit and ride toys. The "console" is elevated, so the tend to stand and straddle the car. I actually like this design more, because they aren't hunched over, they tend to straighten up and play more upright.
It makes a bazillion noises. In that area, I wish it were simpler. There are left and right buttons. Animal buttons. A horn. A gear shift. A key. A car that slides. Plus the bar across the top that lights up. That is a lot of action going on. It can be a little overstimulating, especially at first. (And certain kids are more sensitive to stimulation than others. Mine is not on the super sensitive side, but is easily overwhelmed at first.)
The console is removable, so they can play with it alone. My 15 month old wants it ON the car at all times, though.
This toy says it goes up to 3, but my 3 year old had little interest in this. He hit all the buttons once and moved on. It was too "baby" for him.

title: Fun For Everyone
text: This is a really nice remote controlled plane, however, it was a little above my kid's level. (They're 8, 7, 5, 3, and 1.) So, they had to have help from Dad to fly, which was perfectly fine with him. It does require a lot of batteries. I do wish it was a little more sturdy, my kids aren't exactly easy on toys. But we'll just have to reserve this for a Dad and kid activity.

title: Fun Bow & Arrow for Girls
text: My daughter (8) loves the Nerf Rebelle products. Hunger Games happens to be her favorite movie, so this bow and arrow set was a very big hit! You'll need two AA batteries (they aren't included) for the laser sight option. (Which isn't really accurate, just fun.) These also have messages on the tail of the arrow that you can only see through the red plastic part. I'm not sure what the point is, but my 8 year old daughter thinks it is "cool'.

title: Automatic Weapon
text:
My 8 year old daughter absolutely LOVES the Nerf Rebelle products. I am so glad that they have these. She'd be fine with the Nerf guns her brothers have, but these are a little extra special and she loves that.

This particular blaster is mechanized. I don't love that about it. It requires 4 AA batteries that ARE NOT included! The darts for this gun are not like the other Rebelle products, they have secret messages on them that you can only read behind the red plastic. My daughter thought that was a lot of fun, but was a little bummed not to have more of the designer ones. This is not her favorite of the Rebelle products (The Crossbow is her favorite.) but she likes it! It is a little fun to be able to rapid fire on the boys.

These will work with regular Nerf darts. So, if you're wanting to order extra darts, they are interchangeable.

title: Second Time Around
text: I had one of the first versions that came out for my now 8 year old and 6.5 year old. This is how both of them learned their letters and letter sounds (before age 4). Then LeapFrog did what LeapFrog does and made a newer version with smaller pieces. This meant the WordWhammer, which was the next step up wouldn't work with the magnets we already had, so we abandoned this product. Now, I'm teaching my 5 and 3 year old their letter and letter sounds, so I figure I'll give Fridge Phonics another shot. The magnets are the smaller ones, but they have added more songs and options. Now, the "A say 'a'" isn't the only thing you hear. I think it is a little too busy now, but the boys like it. Hopefully it'll help them as they learn their letter sounds.

title: Oh! The Parts!
text:
Why do all these plastic web pieces look like something Mr. Freeze would have and not Spider-Man? I guess there is not good way to make a plastic web. So, why try?
The web attachments were very easily bent and broken. So, our Spider-Man was attachementless in a few says of play. He does talk, which the kids like. However, I don't see how this is better than the cheaper non-attachement version. Save yourself the frustration and money and just buy the simpler figure with no Mr. Freeze attachments.

title: Why Did They Put A Gun On It?!
text:
This helmet without the little gun attachment would have received 4 stars. However, they added the little gun.
The gun slides into either side or the top of the helmet. A push of the button shoots narrow plastic darts. The darts bend easily, so once stepped on, one of the darts would no longer go back into the gun. (Eliciting much screaming and yelling about who stepped on the dart and "broke it forever!")
The mask itself has a light up feature. The eyebrows light up when you turn the lights on. 2 of my boys thought this was awesome. One hated the red light in his eyes.
The internal portion of the mask has a nose piece that sits on the kid's nose. It has rubber around it to sit comfortably. If you have a kid who is weird about things touching their nose, this mask is not for you.
The back adjusts horizontally and vertically, so you can get a pretty good fit on any kid. It can be made to fit my 2 year old or my 8 year old. The problem is that there are rows of little holes that have to line up with the row of little dots. My 6 and 8 year old can size it themselves, but the 2 and 4 year old come to me every time they need it sized. If someone completely unsnaps the whole thing, the 6 and 8 year old cannot get everything laced back properly. (You have to pull one strap through another and tuck the end behind a tab.)
Overall, the mask is okay. They enjoy playing with it. I just wish it was only a mask.

title: Horrible Design
text: My kids (7, 6, 4, 2, and 10 months) were super excited about this toy. As I waged war against the packaging, they stood ready to pounce on it as soon as it was freed. It took so long, a few of them wandered off before freedom was actually achieved. It was far too complicated for the 2 year old to understand. He simply kept the shield closed and yelled "Bam!" That was the happiest any of them have been with this toy. Once the 4 and 6 year olds could get their hands on it and pull one end to open the gun then squeeze the other end to fire the gun, the fun ended and the screaming and "I hate this toy!" began. First, it takes almost adult strength and dexterity to pull the thing open. The yankings of a 4 and 6 year old quickly broke the mechanism that flips the gun part around toward the front. It is also ridiculously difficult, even for me, to get those guns back down into the shield. They darts are under Nerf quality. Though they are Nerf style and size, so easily replaceable. But the gun only worked for a few days before it bit the dust. Now, it is just a shield. Save yourself the trouble and just get a shield without the gun to begin with. The design is awful. It just isn't built to withstand any amount of kid use.

title: Works With The "Others"
text: My kids are "little building block" enthusiasts. They love them. But they can get very pricey, very fast.
